comments: This is the second computer organization course and focuses on computer hardware design. Topics covered are: (1) basic digital system design including finite state machines, (2) instruction set design and simple RISC assembly programming, (3) quantitative evaluation of computer performance, (4) circuits for integer and floating-point arithmetic, (5) data path and control, (6) micro-programming, (7) pipelining, (8) storage hierarchy and virtual memory, (9) input/output, (10) different forms of parallelism including instruction level parallelism, data-level parallelism using both vectors and message-passing multi-processors, and thread-level parallelism using shared memory multiprocessors and basic cache coherence and synchronization.  All student comments are unanimous in that the class was challenging but very interesting. Many students felt that class organization could be dramatically improved, as some students felt that they were were “guinea pigs” for the TAs, but all comments agreed that TAs were very helpful and engaging.  Students generally agreed that Professor Martin was “amazing” and knew how to engage the students in the subject matter.   Toward the end of the class, the workload became very heavy, but that did not seem to affect students’ overall opinions of the class.
